Precast prestressed floor slabs used as permanent spans between stringers shall be designed compositely with the in-place concrete portion of the slab to support additional dead and live loads. b. The floor slab shall be analyzed assuming it supports its self-weight, construction load, and the weight of the in-place concrete, and it is assumed to act compositely with the in-place concrete to resist moments due to additional dead and live loads. 4. 5.5 General Design (1) General Provisions① Design theory and general considerations shall comply with the specified required strength. PSC structures are often difficult to repair, reinforce, or modify, so thorough investigation should be conducted before design, and appropriate judgment should be made based on the results to prevent defects or deformations harmful to the structure, such as cracks and breakage. To this end, the load on the structure, temperature changes, meteorological effects, ground support, and in special cases, the influence of earthquakes, should be thoroughly investigated based on test results and past experience. Furthermore, considering the importance assessment of the structure, the difficulty of repair, aesthetics, and other site conditions, the structural form, allowable stress, and structural details that can act on them should be determined and the design should be made accordingly.② Design shall be based on strength (strength design method) and behavior under service conditions (allowable stress design). In this case, all loading stages used, from the introduction of prestress to the end of the structure's service life, should consider all possible extreme cases. The active load stages to be considered in design are as follows. (a) At the time of prestress introduction: The tensile force of the prestressing tendon is at its maximum, while the strength of the concrete is at its minimum. (b) During service load application: Volume changes occur in the PSC structure as the load acts for an extended period. (c) During factored load application: A resistance calculation is necessary to verify the safety of the member. In addition, consideration should be given to crack load stages, transportation and erection load stages, and so on.③ The stress concentration phenomenon due to prestressing should be considered in the design. Prestressing causes stress to concentrate at the anchorage, the bending or curvature portions of the prestressing tendon, etc. The influence of this stress concentration on the member should be examined in the design, and appropriate reinforcement should be provided accordingly.④ The effects of temperature, drying shrinkage, creep, and relaxation of the pre-tensioning steel should be considered. (2) Basic AssumptionsThe following assumptions apply to the design purpose of a monolithic member.① The strain varies linearly with depth throughout the member for all load ranges. However, in deep beams, the strain distribution is non-linear, so this should be considered in analysis and design.② Before cracking occurs, stress is proportional to strain in a linear relationship.③ After cracking occurs, the tensile strength of concrete is neglected. (3) Composite Flexural MembersA composite girder flexural member, which is composed of precast elements and cast-in-place concrete elements, but behaves as a whole under acting loads, shall be designed in accordance with the following provisions.① Until the supporting member required to support all loads and limit deflection and cracking is completed, the props shall not be removed.② Fully composite or partially composite members shall be designed to resist shear force and moment. Individual structural elements shall be investigated for all critical load stages, and designed to resist all loads introduced before the design strength of the composite member is fully developed. Reinforcing bars shall be arranged as needed to prevent separation of individual structural elements.③ If the specified strength, unit weight, or other properties of multiple structural elements are different, the properties or critical values of the individual structural elements shall be used in the design.④ When calculating the flexural strength of a composite member by the strength design method, the member supported by props shall not be distinguished from the member not supported by props.⑤ Shear reinforcement shall be fully anchored to the connection structural elements in accordance with the anchorage provisions for shear reinforcement. The anchored shear reinforcement may be included as horizontal shear reinforcement (ties).⑥ Design on a cross-section assuming that the entire member resists vertical shear force is 4. "5.12(1) in" 4. shall comply with clause 5.12(4). The design shall ensure that horizontal shear force is completely transferred at the contact surface of the intersecting member, and the design for horizontal shear force shall... 4. 5.12(4)④ provision shall be followed.⑧ In structures consisting of precast beams with cast-in-place slabs, tensile stresses occur in the bottom portion of the beam and the slab due to different drying shrinkage. Since tensile drying shrinkage occurs over a sustained period, the effect of drying shrinkage on the beam is reduced by creep. Different drying shrinkage affects crack loads and the deflection curve of the beam. When these factors are particularly important, the effect of different drying shrinkage shall be added to the effect of load. (4) The strength of the calculated member shall not be less than the largest value calculated in the load factor design. The strength reduction factor is as follows. ① Flexural members, prestressed concrete members receiving bending and axial force under quality control conditions for factory-produced precast prestressed members ② Shear strength   For all other cases 4. It complies with the strength reduction factor of 4.2(2)②. 4. 5.6 Prestressing (1) Prestress force is considered as an external equivalent load, in accordance with KDS 24 12 20 (" 4. shall be calculated according to 1.2(8)).(2) The allowable stress of the prestressing tendon① When tensioning the prestressing tendon, the tensile stress of the prestressing tendon is. or The smaller value of 0.94 must be observed. ② Immediately after the introduction of prestress, the tensile stress of the prestressing tendons shall not exceed the following value. A. Pretensioning ................................. 0.8 or The smaller value of 0.9. Post-tensioning ............................. 0.7 or The compressive strength of concrete when prestress is introduced① is the maximum compressive stress occurring in the concrete immediately after prestressing. It must not exceed 1.7 times. The compressive strength of concrete at the time of prestressing must have a certain safety factor with respect to the maximum compressive stress immediately after prestressing. This maximum compressive stress is reduced by factors such as relaxation of PS steel, creep of concrete, drying shrinkage, and dead load, so the safety factor in this case may be less than the safety factor at the time of design load application. However, if the prestressing force is excessive, the creep of concrete will exceed the range proportional to the stress, so the maximum compressive stress shall not exceed 60% of the concrete compressive strength. 1.7 times or greater safety factor shall be stipulated. However, unless otherwise specified, the compressive strength of the concrete specimen, which has been cured under the same curing conditions as the member, shall be such that no force is applied to the concrete until the compressive strength reaches 30 MPa for prestressed members and 27 MPa for post-tensioned members. The reason for setting the concrete compressive strength at 30 MPa or higher during prestressing in the prestressing method is to ensure a safety factor against the maximum compressive stress in the concrete, as well as to require sufficient bond strength between the PS tendon and the concrete, which is taken into consideration. ② When introducing prestress, the concrete near the anchorage portion must have a strength sufficient to withstand the compressive stress generated by the anchorage. The local compressive or tensile stress generated by the anchorage of the PS tendon varies depending on the type of anchorage device, the spacing of the anchorage devices, and the concrete cover thickness. Therefore, the concrete strength near the anchorage device should reach the concrete strength stipulated in the design methods of each PSC construction method before the PS tendon is tensioned. In particular, when tensioning the PS tendon at an early age of concrete, sufficient attention should be paid to the spacing of the anchorage devices and the concrete cover thickness, and safety should be secured by testing if necessary. (4) The prestressing loss is not equal to the tensile capacity measured by the tensioning device when the PS tendon is initially tensioned. A considerable amount of the tensile capacity is lost due to various reasons during or after the tensioning process. The effective prestress is the value obtained by subtracting the loss due to various reasons from the initial prestress when initially tensioned. The difference between the calculated prestress loss and the actual loss does not affect the design strength of the member, but it affects the behavior of the structure under working loads, such as deflection, uplift, and cracking. For example, if the prestress loss is overestimated when working loads are applied, it will have the effect of applying an excessively large prestress during actual construction, which can lead to excessive uplift and undesirable horizontal displacement of the structure. ① The initial prestress force immediately after prestressing shall be calculated by considering the loss due to the following influences on the tensile end of the PS tendon. a. Friction between the PS tendon and the sheath b. Slip at the anchorage device c. PSC box bridges with post-tensioning shall be designed to allow for the application of 15% of the prestressing force required for design calculations longitudinally as additional prestressing. This additional prestressing shall be designed to be available whenever necessary during the service life of the structure. This additional prestressing is within this design standard. 1.2. To maintain the safety conditions of the review grade defined in Article 1.2, a correction of up to 15% compressive stress loss is permitted for any section. b. Even in the absence of compressive loss, additional prestressing loads shall be considered to maintain the aforementioned safety conditions. c. Therefore, additional buttresses and deviation blocks shall be provided for the additional tensioning members located outside the concrete within the duct. This shall be reviewed for local bending and tension. (2) Design Review ① The entire structure shall be reviewed as follows: a. Service load design (service load design combinations) to avoid undesirable phenomena. b. Coefficient load design (coefficient load design combinations) to review the static equilibrium, strength, and stability of structural elements. ② Safety operating criteria shall be suitable for all service load conditions, including flood, wind, or seismic loads. ③ All displacement reviews shall utilize stable ground, such as bedrock or sound, deep alluvium, for multiple piers. Replicable seismic wave periods and amplitudes shall be considered for this ground, and relative displacement shall be added to the displacement review. Fault displacement in the relevant area shall also be considered. ④ Displacement shall be calculated as the sum of individual displacements, such as foundation, pier, bearing, deck, and connector displacements, but this design standard's KDS 24 10 10( 4.2) The displacement to be reviewed according to 4.2 is the relative displacement between a structure and an adjacent structure. (3) Stress Calculation ① In most cases, a linear elastic model can be used for stress calculation. This linear elastic model is not suitable for the strength design of indeterminate structures, but it can be used in unavoidable cases. ② Structures shall be designed considering temporary support methods. Unhardened concrete during placement can act as a live load on the supporting structure, inducing stress and displacement in bridges, among others. ③ In bridges involving multiple construction processes, simplified equations may be used for the calculation of displacement and stress due to creep and drying shrinkage of concrete only when specified by the relevant authorities. ④ Prestressing load: for the anchorage zone and local zone of the prestressing tendon, 4. According to 5.15, a special analysis shall be performed. (4) Design loads: Load combinations and load factors as defined in KDS 24 12 10 shall be considered. (5) Design stress for factored loads: Factored load combinations, including exceptional load combinations such as accident loads, shall be considered in accordance with KDS 24 12 10 of this design standard. 4. 2.4) shall apply. (6) The load combinations to be considered in design stress calculations shall be in accordance with KDS 24 12 10 (" 4. Shall comply with 2.3)② This design standard. 4. Additional prestressing as defined in 5.7(1)③ shall be considered together with the service load combinations. (7) Static balance checking ① A static balance check shall be performed in accordance with KDS 24 10 10 of this design standard. ② The static balance check shall be performed for the entire structure and each construction stage. ③ At each temporary stage, static equilibrium shall be satisfied by considering wind load, temperature load, and temporary load, and in particular, for bridges involving multiple construction processes such as the MSS method or the FCM (Free cantilever method) method, such review shall not be omitted. 4. 5.8 Section (1) Definitions. a. Gross Section: The gross section refers to the section formed by the outer perimeter of the concrete, excluding reinforcing bars or ducts, etc. b. Effective Section: The effective section refers to the net section of the concrete, excluding duct holes, anchorages, etc., for placing longitudinal and transverse reinforcing bars, even though they may be filled after construction. c. Transformed Section (Homogeneous Section): The transformed section is a section where the area of the longitudinal PS reinforcement, multiplied by the ratio of the elastic modulus, is added to the effective section, assuming that the PS reinforcement is perfectly bonded. (2) Section Applied to Stress Calculation ① The gross section shall be used when calculating the following: a. Self-weight of the bridge b. Stiffness of elements for indeterminate force calculation c. Strain of bridge members included in Inspection Grade II ② Cracked section (effective section or transformed section) shall be used when calculating section stresses for Inspection Grades I and II. ③ The effective section shall be used when calculating stresses due to fixed loads in the service load design. ④ Cracked section, ignoring the tensile stress of concrete, shall be used when inspecting bridge or bridge elements in Inspection Grade III. (3) Concrete Cover Thickness Section ① When there is no bending stress component, the concrete cover thickness section is the gross section. ② When there is a bending stress component, the concrete cover thickness section refers to a section consisting of two straight lines parallel to the bending axis, which is a distance c from the PS reinforcement, where the outer perimeter of the section and the PS reinforcement are considered, and c is the minimum concrete cover thickness of the PS reinforcement. 4. For railroad bridges, tensile stress shall not occur in rare load combinations including permanent live loads and standard vehicle loads. c. For Grade II, tensile stress shall be checked for construction or temporary conditions and the most unfavorable combinations. ② Allowable Stress The design of precast prestressed members generally uses 35 MPa as the standard. However, if the engineer determines that a consistent strength can be maintained, the concrete strength may be increased to 42 MPa. Higher strength concrete may also be designed in specific areas (on an individual area basis). In such cases, the design documents shall include a note stating that the engineer shall thoroughly supervise the materials and construction process to obtain the required strength. The provisions of this section also apply equally to prestressed concrete structures and structural elements designed with low concrete strengths. The allowable tensile stress of PS strands does not differentiate between temporary prestress and effective prestress. This is because the initial PS strand stress immediately after prestressing continues for a considerable period after the structure is used, so the initial PS strand stress cannot be considered a temporary stress. Since the continuous decrease in PS strand stress due to prestress loss improves the condition of the PS strand, no limits are imposed on this stress reduction in the specification. a. Allowable Stress of PS Strands (a) Stress at the anchorage after (seating) ⓑ Pretension member. Stress-relieved strands. . Low relaxation strands. To compensate for the loss due to the activity of the anchorage device, it is permissible for the stress to increase up to a certain value for a short time, and the stress after anchoring shall not exceed the above value. Ⓒ Post-tension member. To compensate for the loss due to the activity of the anchorage device and the loss due to friction, it is permissible for the stress to increase up to a certain value for a short time, and the stress at the anchorage after anchoring shall not exceed the above value. The lateral dimensions of the anchorage zone at the ends of the member or segment are taken as the depth and width of the cross-section. The longitudinal length of the anchorage zone in the direction of the tensioning reinforcement (ahead of the anchorage device) shall not exceed the length of the member or segment and shall not be less than the larger of the lateral dimensions. It shall not exceed 1.5 times. In the case of settlement in the middle, the length of the settlement zone shall be extended by a distance not less than the larger of the lateral dimensions behind the anchoring device. Since the settlement zone is a region setting value for the settlement analysis, it is not necessary to maintain the same cross-section in the direction of the tensioning member, but safety shall be secured through local analysis of the settlement and bearing parts, and overall structural system analysis. When using multiple anchoring devices in a slab, the width and length of the settlement zone shall be equal to the center spacing of the tensioning members on which stress is acting, but shall not exceed the slab length in the axial direction of the tensioning member. The thickness of the settlement zone shall be taken as equal to the slab thickness. (2) In prestressed members, vertical bars shall be arranged within the span from the end of the beam to resist the cracking force of the settlement zone to resist at least 4% of the total prestress force when introducing tension. The vertical bars should be positioned as close to the end as possible. At this time, the stress of the reinforcing bar shall not exceed 140 MPa. Nominal reinforcing bars shall be arranged to wrap the PS steel arranged on the lower flange up to the distance from the end of the beam. In box-shaped beams, transverse reinforcing bars shall be arranged and the reinforcing bars shall be extended to the web of the box beam and anchored. 4. 5.15 Anchorage Zone, End Strut, and Lower Corner Stability Review (1) In railway bridges with a large amount of PS reinforcement, this review shall not be omitted as per this provision. (2) Since prestress is distributed from the anchorage device of the PS reinforcement to the floor slab, the spacing of the PS reinforcement should be determined considering the size of the anchorage device, the distribution width of the prestress force, etc., so that the prestress is not excessive or insufficient in the design section. (3) Near the support of the pier, the floor slab reinforcement in the longitudinal direction should be arranged in the direction of the support line. Therefore, transverse beams should be provided to increase the stiffness in the direction perpendicular to the main girder. When the angle is 45° or greater, the transverse beam should be placed perpendicular to the main girder, but a sufficient review of the torsional deformation should be performed. When the angle is less than 45°, the transverse beam may be installed parallel to the support line. (2) Intermediate transverse beams shall be installed at one location or more per span, or at intervals of 15 m or less. 4. 1 0.3 Structural Analysis (1) The shear force of the girder shall be calculated based on the grid structural theory. However, when the spacing of the floor slab is short and can be considered as a plate structure, the shear force may be calculated according to the orthotropic plate theory. The section force due to live load shall be the section force obtained by applying the live load to the width of the floor slab and dividing it by the number of main beams, multiplied by the flanged coefficient for I-beams, or by a specified factor for other types of beams (Table). (2) The basic cross-sectional shape of a box girder bridge is shown in the figure. As shown in Figure 4.13-1, there are single-box girder bridges, multi-row box girder bridges, and multi-box girder bridges. (3) Figure Figure 4.13-2 shows various shapes of box girder bridges with box section characteristics. Basic Cross-Section Shape Diagram of Box Girder Bridge 4.13-1 Box Girder Bridges with Various Shapes (4.13-2) 4. 1 3.2 General Design (1) Longitudinal beams and transverse walls shall be provided at the bearing points of the main girders. (2) For multi-box girders with a span of 24 m or more, intermediate longitudinal beams and intermediate transverse walls shall be installed. When longitudinal beams are placed within a span, they shall be located at the position of the maximum bending moment. (3) For single and multiple box girders that are straight bridges or curved bridges with an inner radius of curvature of 240 m or more, intermediate transverse walls are not required. (4) For single and multiple box girders with a radius of curvature less than 240 m, intermediate transverse walls may be required, and the spacing and strength of the intermediate transverse walls shall be carefully reviewed in the design. In this case, the spacing of the intermediate transverse walls should be 12 m or less. (5) The width of the web used in the calculation of shear stress shall be the thickness in the direction perpendicular to the web axis. For example, in the case of an inclined web, refer to the figure. As shown in Figure 4.13-3, the width in the orthogonal direction of the shear flow can be used. Figure. When the flange width used in calculating shear stress (4.13-3) is large compared to the thickness of the web or flange, it is advisable to check the shear force generated in the flange. In particular, when the web width exceeds four times the flange thickness, or in the case of box girder bridges with stiffening ribs, it is necessary to investigate the horizontal shear stress generated in the flange. Figure The distribution of horizontal shear stress occurring on the flange (7) in a box girder assumes that the entire slab width of the compression flange is effective in compression. 4. 1 "3.3 Structural Analysis (1) The section forces of single-box girder bridges and multi-box girder bridges can be calculated according to Vierendeel theory. Generally, single-box girder bridges and multi-box girder bridges can be analyzed as if the box girder cross-section is a single beam because they have high stiffness in the direction perpendicular to the bridge axis and good load distribution characteristics. However, the ratio of the overall width to the span (overall width/span) that" For multi-box girders with a relatively wide width exceeding 0.5, it is preferable to calculate section forces using lattice theory (2). The section forces of box girders with chamfers and multi-column box girders shall be calculated according to lattice theory. However, in single box girders and multi-box girders where the chamfer angle is less than 20°, it is also acceptable to interpret them using Vlasov theory instead of lattice theory. 4. 1 3.4 Lateral Design (1) The stress in the lower flange and web of a box girder may be analyzed by considering it as a frame structure consisting of the web and upper and lower flanges. Figure. As shown in Figures 4.13-15, modeling the structure as a box girder with a thickness of 1 m in the transverse direction and performing calculations yields sufficiently accurate results in practice. Therefore, this method can be used for general calculations. Since the axial force generated in the member due to loads other than prestress is generally small, the axial force need not be considered when designing the lower flange and web. Figure. 4.13-5 Bending Moment of Lower Flange and Web (2) The section forces of the lower flange and web of box girder bridges with inclined webs and stiffening ribs shall be determined considering the influence of the web inclination and the stiffening ribs. In box girder bridges with inclined webs, if the PS reinforcement arranged in the web in the bridge axis direction is upwardly curved, the section forces due to the vertical component of the prestress force, etc., shall be reviewed. However, the section forces of box girder bridges with stiffening ribs shall be calculated considering the influence of the ribs. In box girder bridges with varying girder height, section forces are generated due to the vertical stress and the vertical component of the prestress force acting on the lower flange. Therefore, if the width of the lower flange is large and its influence is not negligible, it should be considered in the design. (3) For the bending moment of the web, half of the amount of reinforcement arranged may be considered as tension reinforcement in the bridge axis direction design. Classifying arch bridges structurally, they are categorized as fixed arches, 1-hinge arches, 2-hinge arches, 3-hinge arches, and so on. (2) The structural type identification of arch bridges includes open-web arches and closed-web arch bridges. (3) Symbols: Arch height : Unit fixed load at springing (kN/m) : Unit fixed load at crown (kN/m) : Slenderness ratio 4. 1 4.2 General Design (1) Arch Axis ① The arch axis should be selected to match the pressure lines caused by load as closely as possible. ② Generally, the load used to determine the pressure line for defining the arch axis should be the dead load or the dead load plus half of the uniformly distributed live load at the fully loaded condition. ③ The arch axis is generally based on formula (" It shall be determined according to Figure 4.14-1. 4. 1 4.1 Arch Axis ( 4.14-1) Here, (2) Arch Superstructure ① The superstructure of open arches shall be designed as a rigid frame structure. ② For closed arches, it is recommended to attach transverse bulkheads at appropriate intervals on the side walls. To prevent the side walls and arch from moving integrally, vertical connections shall be installed at appropriate intervals on the side walls. (3) For arches with long spans, it is necessary to check for buckling safety. (4) The foundation of the arch shall be able to sufficiently resist the horizontal forces generated by the arch. (5) It shall be confirmed that the arch rib is safe against buckling in the plane and out of plane. ① When designing the arch rib, stability against buckling in the plane and out of plane shall be verified in addition to the inspection of stress and shear force. As an example of the in-plane buckling check for reinforced concrete arch bridges, DIN (" 1 nine eight The application criteria for the inspection method stipulated in 1.4) are as follows. a. ≤ 20: Buckling inspection is not required. b. 20 ≤ 70: The effect of finite deformation shall be replaced by the bending moment due to an eccentric load, added to the applied moment, and the stability of the cross-section with respect to bending moment shall be reviewed. c. 70 ≤ 200: In addition to the effect of finite deformation, the stability against buckling shall be checked, considering the nonlinearity of the material of the reinforced concrete member. d. 200: Unsuitable as a structure. 4. 1 4.3 Structural Analysis (1) Arches include two-hinged arches, three-hinged arches, fixed arches, among others; however, this section only discusses fixed arches, which are primarily used in railway bridges. (2) The degree of indeterminacy of an arch must be determined by elastic theory. (3) When designing an arch, the effects of temperature changes and concrete shrinkage, in addition to vertical and horizontal loads, must be considered. (4) The arch should be designed considering the influence of the shape of the arch axis and the variation of the second moment of area of each section on the degree of indeterminacy. 4. 1 4.4 Handling Loads (1) Generally, the section is determined by a combination of dead load + live load + impact + temperature change + drying shrinkage load, and other load combinations should also be reviewed. If the section is insufficient, the section should be modified. (2) Live load is shown in the table. (3) Expansion joints shall be installed on the sidewalls of a closed arch at springing and other suitable locations.
